trans-unit.source: Interpreting Expressions
trans-unit.target: Interpreting Expressions

trans-unit.source: Previous -- Executing Expressions
trans-unit.target: Previous -- Executing Expressions

trans-unit.source: Now, let's write some code to examine the structure of an *expression tree*.
trans-unit.target: Now, let's write some code to examine the structure of an *expression tree*.

trans-unit.source: Every node in an expression tree will be an object of a class that is derived from `Expression`.
trans-unit.target: Every node in an expression tree will be an object of a class that is derived from `Expression`.

trans-unit.source: That design makes visiting all the nodes in an expression tree a relatively straight forward recursive operation.
trans-unit.target: That design makes visiting all the nodes in an expression tree a relatively straight forward recursive operation.

trans-unit.source: The general strategy is to start at the root node and determine what kind of node it is.
trans-unit.target: The general strategy is to start at the root node and determine what kind of node it is.

trans-unit.source: If the node type has children, recursively visit the children.
trans-unit.target: If the node type has children, recursively visit the children.

trans-unit.source: At each child node, repeat the process used at the root node: determine the type, and if the type has children, visit each of the children.
trans-unit.target: At each child node, repeat the process used at the root node: determine the type, and if the type has children, visit each of the children.

trans-unit.source: Examining an Expression with No Children
trans-unit.target: Examining an Expression with No Children

trans-unit.source: Let's start by visiting each node in a very simple expression tree.
trans-unit.target: Let's start by visiting each node in a very simple expression tree.

trans-unit.source: Here's the code that creates a constant expression and then examines its properties:
trans-unit.target: Here's the code that creates a constant expression and then examines its properties:

trans-unit.target: This will print the following:

trans-unit.target: Now, let's write the code that would examine this expression and write out some important properties about it.

trans-unit.source: Here's that code:
trans-unit.target: Here's that code:

trans-unit.source: Examining a simple Addition Expression
trans-unit.target: Examining a simple Addition Expression

trans-unit.source: Let's start with the addition sample from the introduction to this section.
trans-unit.target: Let's start with the addition sample from the introduction to this section.

trans-unit.source: I'm not using `var` to declare this expression tree, as it is not possible because the right-hand side of the assignment is implicitly typed.
trans-unit.target: I'm not using `var` to declare this expression tree, as it is not possible because the right-hand side of the assignment is implicitly typed.

trans-unit.source: To understand this more deeply, read [here](implicitly-typed-lambda-expressions.md).
trans-unit.target: To understand this more deeply, read [here](implicitly-typed-lambda-expressions.md).

trans-unit.source: The root node is a `LambaExpression`.
trans-unit.target: The root node is a `LambaExpression`.

trans-unit.source: In order to get the interesting code on the right hand side of the `=>` operator, you need to find one of the children of the `LambdaExpression`.
trans-unit.target: In order to get the interesting code on the right hand side of the `=>` operator, you need to find one of the children of the `LambdaExpression`.

trans-unit.source: We'll do that with all the expressions in this section.
trans-unit.target: We'll do that with all the expressions in this section.

trans-unit.source: The parent node does help us find the return type of the `LambdaExpression`.
trans-unit.target: The parent node does help us find the return type of the `LambdaExpression`.

trans-unit.source: To examine each node in this expression, we'll need to recursively visit a number of nodes.
trans-unit.target: To examine each node in this expression, we'll need to recursively visit a number of nodes.

trans-unit.source: Here's a simple first implementation:
trans-unit.target: Here's a simple first implementation:

trans-unit.source: This sample prints the following output:
trans-unit.target: This sample prints the following output:

trans-unit.source: You'll notice a lot of repetition in the code sample above.
trans-unit.target: You'll notice a lot of repetition in the code sample above.

trans-unit.source: Let's clean that up and build a more general purpose expression node visitor.
trans-unit.target: Let's clean that up and build a more general purpose expression node visitor.

trans-unit.source: That's going to require us to write a recursive algorithm.
trans-unit.target: That's going to require us to write a recursive algorithm.

trans-unit.source: Any node could be of a type that might have children.
trans-unit.target: Any node could be of a type that might have children.

trans-unit.source: Any node that has children requires us to visit those children and determine what that node is.
trans-unit.target: Any node that has children requires us to visit those children and determine what that node is.

trans-unit.source: Here's the cleaned up version that utilizes recursion to visit the addition operations:
trans-unit.target: Here's the cleaned up version that utilizes recursion to visit the addition operations:

trans-unit.source: This algorithm is the basis of an algorithm that can visit any arbitrary `LambdaExpression`.
trans-unit.target: This algorithm is the basis of an algorithm that can visit any arbitrary `LambdaExpression`.

trans-unit.source: There are a lot of holes, namely that the code I created only looks for a very small sample of the possible sets of expression tree nodes that it may encounter.
trans-unit.target: There are a lot of holes, namely that the code I created only looks for a very small sample of the possible sets of expression tree nodes that it may encounter.

trans-unit.source: However, you can still learn quite a bit from what it produces.
trans-unit.target: However, you can still learn quite a bit from what it produces.

trans-unit.source: (The default case in the `Visitor.CreateFromExpression` method prints a message to the error console when a new node type is encountered.
trans-unit.target: (The default case in the `Visitor.CreateFromExpression` method prints a message to the error console when a new node type is encountered.

trans-unit.source: That way, you know to add a new expression type.)
trans-unit.target: That way, you know to add a new expression type.)

trans-unit.source: When you run this visitor on the addition expression shown above, you get the following output:
trans-unit.target: When you run this visitor on the addition expression shown above, you get the following output:

trans-unit.source: Now that you've built a more general visitor implementation, you can visit and process many more different types of expressions.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've built a more general visitor implementation, you can visit and process many more different types of expressions.

trans-unit.source: Examining an Addition Expression with Many Levels
trans-unit.target: Examining an Addition Expression with Many Levels

trans-unit.source: Let's try a more complicated example, yet still limit the node types to addition only:
trans-unit.target: Let's try a more complicated example, yet still limit the node types to addition only:

trans-unit.source: Before you run this on the visitor algorithm, try a thought exercise to work out what the output might be.
trans-unit.target: Before you run this on the visitor algorithm, try a thought exercise to work out what the output might be.

trans-unit.source: Remember that the `+` operator is a *binary operator*: it must have two children, representing the left and right operands.
trans-unit.target: Remember that the `+` operator is a *binary operator*: it must have two children, representing the left and right operands.

trans-unit.source: There are several possible ways to construct a tree that could be correct:
trans-unit.target: There are several possible ways to construct a tree that could be correct:

trans-unit.source: You can see the separation into two possible answers to highlight the most promising.
trans-unit.target: You can see the separation into two possible answers to highlight the most promising.

trans-unit.source: The first represents *right associative* expressions.
trans-unit.target: The first represents *right associative* expressions.

trans-unit.source: The second represent *left associative* expressions.
trans-unit.target: The second represent *left associative* expressions.

trans-unit.source: The advantage of both of those two formats is that the format scales to any arbitrary number of addition expressions.
trans-unit.target: The advantage of both of those two formats is that the format scales to any arbitrary number of addition expressions.

trans-unit.source: If you do run this expression through the visitor, you will see this this output, verifying that the simple addition expression is *left associative*.
trans-unit.target: If you do run this expression through the visitor, you will see this this output, verifying that the simple addition expression is *left associative*.

trans-unit.source: In order to run this sample, and see the full expression tree, I had to make one change to the source expression tree.
trans-unit.target: In order to run this sample, and see the full expression tree, I had to make one change to the source expression tree.

trans-unit.source: When the expression tree contains all constants, the resulting tree simply contains the constant value of `10`.
trans-unit.target: When the expression tree contains all constants, the resulting tree simply contains the constant value of `10`.

trans-unit.source: The compiler performs all the addition and reduces the expression to its simplest form.
trans-unit.target: The compiler performs all the addition and reduces the expression to its simplest form.

trans-unit.source: Simply adding one variable in the expression is sufficient to see the original tree:
trans-unit.target: Simply adding one variable in the expression is sufficient to see the original tree:

trans-unit.source: Create a visitor for this sum and run the visitor you'll see this output:
trans-unit.target: Create a visitor for this sum and run the visitor you'll see this output:

trans-unit.source: You can also run any of the other samples through the visitor code and see what tree it represents.
trans-unit.target: You can also run any of the other samples through the visitor code and see what tree it represents.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example of the `sum3` expression above (with an additional parameter to prevent the compiler from computing the constant):
trans-unit.target: Here's an example of the `sum3` expression above (with an additional parameter to prevent the compiler from computing the constant):

trans-unit.source: Here's the output from the visitor:
trans-unit.target: Here's the output from the visitor:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the parentheses are not part of the output.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the parentheses are not part of the output.

trans-unit.source: There are no nodes in the expression tree that represent the parentheses in the input expression.
trans-unit.target: There are no nodes in the expression tree that represent the parentheses in the input expression.

trans-unit.source: The structure of the expression tree contains all the information necessary to communicate the precedence.
trans-unit.target: The structure of the expression tree contains all the information necessary to communicate the precedence.

trans-unit.source: Extending from this sample
trans-unit.target: Extending from this sample

trans-unit.source: The sample deals with only the most rudimentary expression trees.
trans-unit.target: The sample deals with only the most rudimentary expression trees.

trans-unit.source: The code you've seen in this section only handles constant integers and the binary `+` operator.
trans-unit.target: The code you've seen in this section only handles constant integers and the binary `+` operator.

trans-unit.source: As a final sample, let's update the visitor to handle a more complicated expression.
trans-unit.target: As a final sample, let's update the visitor to handle a more complicated expression.

trans-unit.source: Let's make it work for this:
trans-unit.target: Let's make it work for this:

trans-unit.source: This code represents one possible implementation for the mathematical *factorial* function.
trans-unit.target: This code represents one possible implementation for the mathematical *factorial* function.

trans-unit.source: The way I've written this code highlights two limitiations of building expression trees by assigning lambda expressions to Expressions.
trans-unit.target: The way I've written this code highlights two limitiations of building expression trees by assigning lambda expressions to Expressions.

trans-unit.source: First, statement lambdas are not allowed.
trans-unit.target: First, statement lambdas are not allowed.

trans-unit.source: That means I can't use loops, blocks, if / else statements, and other control structures common in C#.
trans-unit.target: That means I can't use loops, blocks, if / else statements, and other control structures common in C#.

trans-unit.source: I'm limited to using expressions.
trans-unit.target: I'm limited to using expressions.

trans-unit.source: Second, I can't recursively call the same expression.
trans-unit.target: Second, I can't recursively call the same expression.

trans-unit.source: I could if it were already a delegate, but I can't call it in its expression tree form.
trans-unit.target: I could if it were already a delegate, but I can't call it in its expression tree form.

trans-unit.source: In the section on [building expression trees](expression-trees-building.md) you'll learn techniques to overcome these limitations.
trans-unit.target: In the section on [building expression trees](expression-trees-building.md) you'll learn techniques to overcome these limitations.

trans-unit.source: In this expression, you'll encounter nodes of all these types:
trans-unit.target: In this expression, you'll encounter nodes of all these types:

trans-unit.source: Equal (binary expression)
trans-unit.target: Equal (binary expression)

trans-unit.source: Multiply (binary expression)
trans-unit.target: Multiply (binary expression)

trans-unit.source: Conditional (the ?
trans-unit.target: Conditional (the ?

trans-unit.source: : expression)
trans-unit.target: : expression)

trans-unit.source: Method Call Expression (calling `Range()` and `Aggregate()`)
trans-unit.target: Method Call Expression (calling `Range()` and `Aggregate()`)

trans-unit.source: One way to modify the visitor algorithm is to keep executing it, and write the node type every time you reach your `default` clause.
trans-unit.target: One way to modify the visitor algorithm is to keep executing it, and write the node type every time you reach your `default` clause.

trans-unit.source: After a few iterations, you'll have seen each of the potential nodes.
trans-unit.target: After a few iterations, you'll have seen each of the potential nodes.

trans-unit.source: Then, you have all you need.
trans-unit.target: Then, you have all you need.

trans-unit.source: The result would be something like this:
trans-unit.target: The result would be something like this:

trans-unit.source: The ConditionalVisitor and MethodCallVisitor process those two nodes:
trans-unit.target: The ConditionalVisitor and MethodCallVisitor process those two nodes:

trans-unit.source: And the output for the expression tree would be:
trans-unit.target: And the output for the expression tree would be:

trans-unit.source: Extending the Sample Library
trans-unit.target: Extending the Sample Library

trans-unit.source: The samples in this section show the core techniques to visit and examine nodes in an expression tree.
trans-unit.target: The samples in this section show the core techniques to visit and examine nodes in an expression tree.

trans-unit.source: I glossed over many actions you might need in order to concentrate on the core tasks of visiting and accessing nodes in an expression tree.
trans-unit.target: I glossed over many actions you might need in order to concentrate on the core tasks of visiting and accessing nodes in an expression tree.

trans-unit.source: First, the visitors only handle constants that are integers.
trans-unit.target: First, the visitors only handle constants that are integers.

trans-unit.source: Constant values could be any other numeric type, and the C# language supports conversions and promotions between those types.
trans-unit.target: Constant values could be any other numeric type, and the C# language supports conversions and promotions between those types.

trans-unit.source: A more robust version of this code would mirror all those capabilities.
trans-unit.target: A more robust version of this code would mirror all those capabilities.

trans-unit.source: Even the last example recognizes a subset of the possible node types.
trans-unit.target: Even the last example recognizes a subset of the possible node types.

trans-unit.source: You can still feed it many expressions that will cause it to fail.
trans-unit.target: You can still feed it many expressions that will cause it to fail.

trans-unit.source: A full implementation is included in the .NET Standard Library under the name [ExpressionVisitor](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionVisitor) and can handle all the possible node types.
trans-unit.target: A full implementation is included in the .NET Standard Library under the name [ExpressionVisitor](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionVisitor) and can handle all the possible node types.

trans-unit.source: Finally, the library I used in this article was built for demonstration and learning.
trans-unit.target: Finally, the library I used in this article was built for demonstration and learning.

trans-unit.source: It's not optimized.
trans-unit.target: It's not optimized.

trans-unit.source: I wrote it to make the structures used very clear, and to highlight the techniques used to visit the nodes and analyze what's there.
trans-unit.target: I wrote it to make the structures used very clear, and to highlight the techniques used to visit the nodes and analyze what's there.

trans-unit.source: A production implementation would pay more attention to performance than I have.
trans-unit.target: A production implementation would pay more attention to performance than I have.

trans-unit.source: Even with those limitations, you should be well on your way to writing algorithms that read and understand expression trees.
trans-unit.target: Even with those limitations, you should be well on your way to writing algorithms that read and understand expression trees.
